resources.string:
TransientGO for Android
Version %s
https://github.com/sky-map-team/stardroid

Introduction and Quick Start
TransientGO turns your Android-powered mobile phone into a window on the night sky. When you point your phone up you will see a map of the brightest stars, constellations, and planets in that part of the sky.
Next time you see a bright star and want to know what it\'s called, use TransientGO!

Navigation Modes
When first installed TransientGO is in Automatic Mode and uses the phone\'s sensors to show you a map of the sky in the direction you are holding the phone. By switching into Manual Mode, you can drag the map with your finger to explore the sky. Move the trackball or D-pad left and right to rotate the map. On multitouch phones you can also rotate the map with two fingers and use a pinch gesture to zoom in and out.

Night Vision Mode
Night Vision Mode is designed to protect your dark-adapted eyes. When you select the Night Vision menu option, TransientGO will display the map in a red color, dim the screen and switch off the button backlights. Select the option again to revert to normal colors.

Setting Your Location
TransientGO needs your approximate location in order to show you the correct star map. By default, it will determine this from your cellular network. If you are out of range, or have network location disabled it will use your phone\'s GPS. You can also set your location manually via the settings menu, either by supplying a place name or as a latitude and longitude (in degrees.) Note that TransientGO requires a data connection to determine your latitude and longitude from a place name.

Troubleshooting and Limitations
The map is inaccurate.
If you find that the map does not accurately line up with the real sky there could be a number of reasons:
1) Is your compass calibrated? Try holding the phone and rotating your wrist in figures of eight to calibrate it. You may need to repeat this at intervals - this is a feature of the phone, rather than TransientGO.
2) Does the application have an accurate fix on your location? Is your GPS or network location turned on?
3) Do you have the correct time and timezone set? TransientGO needs to calculate Universal Time, and it needs your local time AND timezone to do this. If your device has a SIM card then these will usually be set correctly.
4) Do you have magnetic correction switched on? In some parts of the world the difference between magnetic North and True North can be as much as 20 degrees.
The map does not move
Are you in manual mode? If not, this could be due to an uncalibrated compass. Follow the steps above to \'unstick\' it.

Acknowledgments
TransientGO is based off of "Google Sky Map": Sky Map was originally developed as "Google Sky Map" by Google Inc. and open sourced in 2012. Sky Map uses maps derived from data from:
Centre de Donnees astronomiques de Strasbourg (http://cdsweb.u-strasbg.fr/)
The Bright Star Catalogue, 5th Revised Ed. (Hoffleit D., Warren Jr W.H.)
The HYG Database, HYG v1.0. (http://www.astronexus.com/)
History and Accurate Positions for the NGC/IC Objects (Harold G. Corwin Jr)
Revised New General Catalogue of Nonstellar Astronomical Objects (Sulentic J.W., Tifft W.G.)
SFA Star Charts (http://observe.phy.sfasu.edu/SFAStarCharts/SFAStarChartFAQ.html)
Positions of Solar System Objects are calculated from data provided by the USNO (http://www.usno.navy.mil/USNO/astronomical-applications)
Spherical coverage data obtained from (http://www2.research.att.com/~njas/coverings)
